quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I found this framework travels with me. It's got these five components to it, vision, skills, incentives, resources, action plan, and you need all of those to have change. And then within those buckets you've got to figure out what are the right levers that you need to pull? What are the things that are missing?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A portable change-management framework practitioners can use to diagnose why an initiative is stuck and what lever to pull next.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Someone says, "Hey, you know what? This would be great to build." And you go pull data to go justify why that would be great to build. Call that identify, justify, execute. First you have to really understand from first principles what is actually going on. So understand, identify, execute.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of “data as justification,” replacing it with a first-principles sequence teams can apply to avoid building the wrong thing.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's impact that you're really trying to drop and the impact is only achievable by looking at set of variables related to the environment, the set of variables related to your skills.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A career decision model: maximize impact by explicitly evaluating both environment variables and your own skill variables.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And that's how I knew Lenny, that I had to reschedule with you because I was like, if people are coming up to me and telling me that they're excited, I was like, there is a lot of anticipation.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete story showing how external signals of audience demand can influence prioritization and commitment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Wizard, I can simply upload my screenshot and Wizards AI will turn them into a fully editable UI design that I can then take, make tweaks to and then share with my teams in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete workflow for turning static screenshots into editable designs quickly, reducing iteration time for product feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And when I want to get really creative and explore totally new ways to improve our product experience, I can use Wizard's AI to generate new design concepts from simple text prompts and turn them into interactive prototypes effortlessly.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable method—text prompts to prototypes—for rapid exploration of new UX directions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a reason that over 2.6 million people have trusted Wizard to accelerate every phase of their product lifecycle and speed up time to market.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point used to support the claim that the tool materially speeds product development.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Most founders and finance teams have to couple together a patchwork of tools to reconcile transactions from different sources, work extra hard just to get a holistic view of cash flow and have maps to company priorities, and struggle to get answers from platforms that all speak different languages.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A succinct diagnosis of the common operational failure mode (tool sprawl) that practitioners can use to evaluate their own finance stack.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Apply in minutes at mercury.com and join over 200,000 ambitious startups like mine that trust Mercury to get them to perform at their best.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete scale/adoption metric that signals market validation and can inform vendor shortlisting.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing where to work: impact framework
quotes.text: And so I looked at that situation and I wrote that post and the framework is really that there's impact that you're really trying to drive and that is the thing that is the most important.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Defines the core career decision framework: optimize for impact as the primary objective.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing where to work: impact framework
quotes.text: And the impact is only achievable by looking at two sets of variables, a set of variables related to the environment, a set of variables related to your skills, and really breaking down each and understanding what's happening in the environment bit by bit and what's happening with your skills and where are you hindered structurally within the environment? Where are your skills kind of lacking and what do you have control over?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Gives an actionable diagnostic method for career moves by separating environment constraints from skill gaps and controllables.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing where to work: impact framework
quotes.text: I realized that it's not compensation. Compensation is a reflection of the input, the impact that you're having, and you're leveling how [inaudible 00:09:12] you are, how much scope you have is a derivative of how much impact you're driving.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: pay and scope follow impact rather than being the thing to optimize for directly.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing where to work: impact framework
quotes.text: The more impact you're driving at your company, the more people feel like you can operate independently, you can drive real results the more that scope they'll give you.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Practical guidance on earning autonomy and bigger roles: repeatedly demonstrate impact to expand scope.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing where to work: impact framework
quotes.text: I think for a product manager for example, it's really one, helping to drive extreme clarity about where the problems with the product, where there's opportunities and what is the right focus and prioritization? That is actually a form of impact.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Operationalizes “impact” for PMs as creating clarity and focus—not just shipping features.

quotes.topic_title: Environment variables: manager, scope, resources, culture
quotes.text: And so you are really looking at each one of these variables, and I look at this every year and I say, "How is my manager doing?" How do I think about my manager? How do I think about the resources I have, the scope, the team, the conversation, the company culture and to what extent? And I score them, I score them as a 1 means it's kind of neutral. A 2 means that I'm greatly benefiting from this situation and something even closer to zero is I'm not in a good place. So I assign a score in quarter point increments, 0.25, 0.5, 0.751 up to 2 every year. And I really ask myself, what is the state of each one of these and to what extent do I believe that they can and will change?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for auditing your environment annually and quantifying where it’s helping or hurting your impact.

quotes.topic_title: Environment variables: manager, scope, resources, culture
quotes.text: That's right, and you have to really be honest. I think part of what makes this framework so powerful for me at least, is that it helps you to be honest around what are the things that are limiting your ability to have impact and for your skills to really land? And to what extent do you believe that you can help to change or try to influence the change in the environment?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Emphasizes the key behavior change: using the framework to diagnose constraints and decide what you can realistically influence.

quotes.topic_title: Environment variables: manager, scope, resources, culture
quotes.text: In some ways it was too much scope and to me that was problematic because I really needed to build out, I felt like multiple teams to support the work that we were doing or to break it up; because it was, I mean the pace, the velocity you can imagine at Facebook was incredible.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson that “more scope” can reduce effectiveness unless the org structure and staffing scale with it.

quotes.topic_title: Environment variables: manager, scope, resources, culture
quotes.text: And I felt like between all of the work that we needed to do, the amount of engineering capacity that we had and the amount that was on the table, I felt like I wasn't resourced in a way where I felt like I could actually deliver on all of the things that were necessary without burning myself out. And I felt like I was burning myself out and I couldn't really see the forest through the trees because there was so much to do.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A vivid example of how misaligned scope and resourcing leads to burnout and loss of strategic clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Environment variables: manager, scope, resources, culture
quotes.text: And there were two or three manager changes concurrently, and so I didn't have a manager to lean on that I felt like I had a relationship with to help me to navigate that space.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Shows how manager churn can be a critical environmental variable that blocks execution even with strong teams and resources.

quotes.topic_title: Manager as key lever and aligning incentives
quotes.text: Not all of these variables is created equal and the manager is the most important variable in the environment, because a great manager who is empathetic, who is aware of what's going on, who is a great communicator, has the ability to move the chess pieces around and to fix some of these for you either immediately or in time.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Frames the manager as the highest-leverage “environment variable” that can reshape scope, resources, and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Manager as key lever and aligning incentives
quotes.text: There's no one other than your manager who can really help to increase your scope or to help make sure that the team has the right pieces in place, or dial in some of the issues that you might see in culture.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Clarifies why manager alignment is often the fastest path to changing constraints that feel immovable as an IC.

quotes.topic_title: Manager as key lever and aligning incentives
quotes.text: And so really the question becomes like to what extent have you been able to clearly articulate what are the... And dispassionately articulate, what are the challenges that you're having, you're seeing across some of these variables with your manager?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Gives a concrete tactic: communicate constraints neutrally and explicitly to enable managerial action.

quotes.topic_title: Manager as key lever and aligning incentives
quotes.text: You're never going to always like your manager, right? That's not the... The goal isn't to like your manager.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Challenges the common expectation that a “good” manager relationship requires personal liking rather than mutual respect and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Manager as key lever and aligning incentives
quotes.text: I guess sometimes the real question is, is actually spending time to try to understand what is your manager optimizing?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Introduces an incentives/optimization lens for finding alignment and unlocking scope by helping with what your manager is measured on.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that drive impact: communication and execution
quotes.text: The communication above these, again, not all of these are created equal. I think communication is the one that tends to be the most impactful.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Ranks core product/career skills and highlights communication as the highest-leverage capability.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that drive impact: communication and execution
quotes.text: You see this for people who are poor executors but incredible communicators and they seem to continue to rise and rise because they can tell a great story, but when you look under the covers, there's nothing there. There's no substance there.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A contrarian observation about how communication can outweigh execution in career progression—for better or worse.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that drive impact: communication and execution
quotes.text: So I think being a voracious reader is really, really critical because it helps to build your toolkit and you need arrows in your quiver to really understand how to think about the right framework and the right mentor at the right time.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on continuous learning as a way to expand frameworks and decision tools.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that drive impact: communication and execution
quotes.text: I tell them, it's actually better to have a stable of mentors. You want to have three or four. And ideally, what you do is you meet with each one of them once a month on a different Friday of the month.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete mentorship system (a “stable” with a cadence) that reduces single-mentor dependency and increases learning throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that drive impact: communication and execution
quotes.text: And so if you're really a student of product, you can't just be a student of theory, you've got to be a student of practice too, meaning you're going and you're looking, it's like, "Hey, I'd love to sit in your team meetings. Can I come watch? Or your PM meetings or your leadership meetings."
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Encourages observational learning—studying real execution by sitting in on meetings—to complement theory.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observation and finding mentors
quotes.text: But I watched, George was a really good listener. He had just a really incredible ability to be in a room and hear what was going on, to recast it back and make sure that everyone felt good about where we were and what was being said and the path forward, and really crystallizing the action items and also how people felt about what the next steps were.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete, observable meeting-leadership behavior to emulate: listen, recap, crystallize actions, and validate emotions to build alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observation and finding mentors
quotes.text: You can see him almost winning trust in every moment of that meeting.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A memorable framing of trust-building as something you earn continuously through micro-behaviors in meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observation and finding mentors
quotes.text: It's not, actually. But what was magical about the way he did it. It's like he would name people and their contributions and show how all of this came together into what is the path forward.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Actionable tactic for buy-in: explicitly credit contributors while synthesizing a shared path forward.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observation and finding mentors
quotes.text: Where I see people find the most success is they ask. They tell people what they're working on or what challenges they have and they say, "Do you know someone who I might be able to learn from who has done this or has good thinking about this recently?"
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A practical method for finding mentors via specific problem-based asks rather than generic mentorship requests.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observation and finding mentors
quotes.text: And so that I think is really important because what you do is you're creating a seed, and the seed is there's a triad and you have the person who's looking for the mentor. You have the recommender, the recommender, and then you have the potential mentor.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A simple framework (“triad”) explaining why warm introductions around a shared purpose increase the odds of a productive mentor connection.

quotes.topic_title: Understand work: de-risking before execution
quotes.text: And so that is what I call the anti-pattern of what we want to do and I call that identify, justify, execute.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Names a common failure mode teams fall into—building first and rationalizing later—so practitioners can recognize and avoid it.

quotes.topic_title: Understand work: de-risking before execution
quotes.text: And that is the anti-pattern to what is kind of like the Facebook kind of way of thinking, which is understand, identify, execute, right? So first you have to really understand from first principles what is actually going on.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Introduces the core framework and emphasizes first-principles understanding as a prerequisite to effective execution.

quotes.topic_title: Understand work: de-risking before execution
quotes.text: When I say an intentional affordance, meaning you put it down like Lenny is going to work on this thing. Right. Lenny as a product manager is going to write a strategy. Janice as a designer is going to design a prototype, whatever the thing is, and you put it down as actual an item as opposed to assuming it's going to happen in the background.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational tactic: explicitly schedule “understand work” as real roadmap items with owners, not implicit background activity.

quotes.topic_title: Understand work: de-risking before execution
quotes.text: So every sprint, let's say you do a three-week sprint or a three-month roadmap, you're executing on the things that you have a lot of conviction around and you're also doing understand work in parallel.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Describes a practical operating model—parallel execution plus discovery—to continuously de-risk and inform the next planning cycle.

quotes.topic_title: Understand work: de-risking before execution
quotes.text: I remember when I left Instagram, this is many years ago, but we had 15 teams and we might've been running 12 to 20 experiments a quarter a team, and I would say probably 60 to 70% of them were positive and shippable, which is incredible.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark showing how systematic de-risking can correlate with unusually high experiment win-rates at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing understand work and balancing shipping
quotes.text: I think when I started at YouTube we were doing 60% execution, 40% understand work. Right. And over time, as we understand more and more, the mix shifts. Now my teams are probably doing 80% execution, 20 to or 85% and 20 to 15% understand work.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete ratio-based framework for allocating “understand work” vs. execution that evolves as the team’s knowledge of the problem space increases.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing understand work and balancing shipping
quotes.text: And so it's not just about writing a strategy, it's about saying, okay, if we have these themes of stuff that we want to work on, what do we know with confidence because the data tells us and what do we need to understand because we don't have the data, we don't have the research, we don't have the insights?
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A practical decision lens for separating work you can confidently execute from work that requires targeted learning first.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing understand work and balancing shipping
quotes.text: So the first and most important piece of understand work was instead of shipping iterations to the current product, we needed to actually get the funnel of what was happening.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A specific example of pausing feature iteration to map the end-to-end funnel and identify the highest-leverage gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing understand work and balancing shipping
quotes.text: That's right. Slow down and speed up.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive principle: investing in understanding can increase long-term velocity and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing understand work and balancing shipping
quotes.text: I say, we should choose, sometimes I'll give them guidance. We should choose three to four understand projects that are going to really help this roadmap and figure out what they are.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A simple operational guardrail to prevent analysis paralysis by capping “understand work” to a small portfolio tied to the roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical example: instrumenting Instagram signup funnel
quotes.text: So I think a big takeaway here is if you want to have more impact, move faster, try to spend a little more time understanding the problems you're going after in the opportunity space.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive productivity principle: investing in problem understanding can actually increase speed and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical example: instrumenting Instagram signup funnel
quotes.text: I'll give you a very tactical example is when I joined Instagram in January 2016, believe it or not, the onboarding, the sign-up flow at Instagram had literally no logging to it.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A concrete growth story showing how even major products can lack basic instrumentation, blocking optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical example: instrumenting Instagram signup funnel
quotes.text: And there was eight steps in the funnel and we don't know what is going on.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Highlights the core failure mode of uninstrumented funnels: you can’t locate drop-offs across steps.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical example: instrumenting Instagram signup funnel
quotes.text: So the first bit of understand work was we needed to do the instrumentation of that funnel as fast as possible to get the data to figure out where the drops were happening and what to fix.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A practical methodology: prioritize “understand work” (instrumentation) to unlock targeted fixes and roadmap decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical example: instrumenting Instagram signup funnel
quotes.text: It feels like it gives meaning to stuff that otherwise people would brush aside.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: A naming/mental-model tactic: labeling foundational analysis as “understand work” helps teams value it instead of rushing to ship.

quotes.topic_title: Managing complex change and building shared skill models
quotes.text: And it's called managing complex change. I actually think I got it from business school or something. And it's really interesting. It's got these five components to it. There's vision, skills, incentives, resources, action plan, and you need all of those to have change.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Introduces a reusable change-management framework with five required components practitioners can audit against.

quotes.topic_title: Managing complex change and building shared skill models
quotes.text: Basically what it does is it shows where if you're missing any one component, you get different outcomes. Right. So if you're missing the vision component, you end up in a state of confusion or if you're missing the incentives, you end up in a state of resistance because people aren't incentivized to do the right work. Or if you're missing an action plan, you end up in a state of false starts.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Gives concrete failure modes that help diagnose why change efforts stall (confusion, resistance, false starts).

quotes.topic_title: Managing complex change and building shared skill models
quotes.text: So I use this, and I think about this a lot actually, because when you come in as a leader, as someone who's supposed to influence change, you have to really observe what's happening and figure out what are the challenges anecdotally and what are you observing? And then I figure out where I can plug in and what I can do to make the teams better.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Actionable leadership approach: observe, diagnose, then decide where to intervene to improve a team.

quotes.topic_title: Managing complex change and building shared skill models
quotes.text: And what I tend to find is moving from the right side to the left side of this, like action plans are easier to institute. Right.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Counterintuitive prioritization: start with easier levers (action plans) before harder ones (vision/skills).

quotes.topic_title: Managing complex change and building shared skill models
quotes.text: So I had to build a deck that showed, okay, here's how I think about product craft. Here's a framework for it. Here's how I think about all of these different things. And so now we have a shared language, shared communication for, and a repository of skills that we're going to build.
quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.context: Concrete tactic for scaling teams: create reusable decks/frameworks to establish shared language and skill models.
